column1: This is a Minor Option for Part B of Oxford University's Honour
School of Natural Science (Physics).  It is part of the four-year
course leading to the M.Phys. degree and also part of the three-year
course leading to the B.A. degree.  It is taught by members of the
subdepartment of Atmospheric, Oceanic and Planetary Physics.
This course will introduce the study of the macroscopic physics of
fluid flows. The topics covered will illustrate a variety of aspects
D J Tritton, Physical Fluid Dynamics, 2nd edition (C.U.P.)
T E Faber, Fluid Dynamics for Physicists (C.U.P.)
B Massey and J Ward-Smith, Mechanics of Fluids (Stanley Thornes)
M Van Dyke, An Album of Fluid Motion (Parabolic Press)
For introductory reading: The Feynman Lectures, Vol. II,
The course will cover the following topics:
Lectures 1, 2. Introduction: Examples of fluid flows in
physics, geophysics, aerodynamics, engineering and biology. Fluids as
continua. Newton's Second Law for a small element of fluid, leading to
the Navier-Stokes equation.  Lagrangian and Eulerian
Lectures 3, 4. Some simple models of fluid flows: Exact
solutions of the equations of motion: Poiseuille flow in a pipe,
rotating cylinders.  Vorticity and its physical interpretation.
Electrostatics analogy, applications to aircraft flight.  Water waves
of ship waves. Nonlinear effects: solitons, hydraulic jumps.
Lectures 8, 9. Very viscous flows: Stokes's Law for the drag
on a sphere.  Thin-film flows and applications to lubrication.
